paragraphs.text: A Greek euro exit would hurt Europe - but not as much as it would hurt Greece.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: When the people of Greece go to the polls on 25 January, they will face some fairly fundamental choices
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Contrary to what many politicians and commentators would have you believe, this election is not about whether Greeks want to stay in the euro
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: a majority clearly wants to
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The real question is whether this latest turn in the drama will finally force Greek politicians to act in their country's long-term interest
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Opinion polls suggest that Greek voters oscillate between anger and fear: anger about the enormous costs they have had to bear in the course of the adjustment programme; and fear of what would happen if Alexis Tsipras, head of the hard-left Syriza movement that still leads in the polls, tries to force through another cut in Greece's international debt
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the last debt restructuring in 2012, the creditors already promised to help Greece reduce its debt to more sustainable levels by 2020 - provided Athens continues to improve its budget
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The Greeks have a democratic right to elect a leader who wants to tear up this agreement
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: just as Germans, Dutch, Finns and others have a right to elect governments that insist on such deals being adhered to
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Although Tsipras says he does not want to leave the euro
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: the resulting showdown could force Greece out of the single currency
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Today, the spectre of "Grexit" is more threatening to the Greeks than to the rest of Europe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Reforms in Spain, Portugal and Ireland have made these countries more resilient
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: International rescue funds and the European Central Bank stand ready to help in case panic should nevertheless spread
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Five out of Germany's eight leading economic research institutes think the eurozone could now cope with a Greek exit
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: This does not mean, however, that Germany or the other eurozone countries want Greece to leave
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even if contagion was limited, another worsening of the eurozone crisis would undermine confidence, stunt the region's fragile recovery and make Europe's leaders - many of whom have declared the crisis over- look inept
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The political and economic consequences for other European countries would be severe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Therefore
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: even if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the rest of Europe does not want to be blackmailed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it will likely be ready to talk
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The new Greek government, whether it is led by the incumbent premier Antonis Samaras, Tsipras, or a new coalition, could reasonably demand a new grand bargain
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: under which the ECB-IMF-EC troika of lenders agrees to revisit the debt issue while the Greek government promises to make the economy fit for the future
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Economic reform, however, is hardly what Greek politicians are talking about in this election campaign
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Greek voters face the unenviable choice between re- electing the mainstream politicians who landed Greece in its current mess in the first place, or voting for Tsipras or other populists who make unrealistic promises of higher wages and more security
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The trouble is not that Tsipras is radical
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it is that he is not radical enough
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: By promising state handouts to voters and protection for vested interests, he is perpetuating the dysfunctional system that plunged Greece into crisis
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Over the past few years, the ruling coalition between the two established parties has tried a tricky balancing act of preserving the system of bureaucratic cronyism that since the 1970s they have helped to build, and modernising Greece's state and economy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as promised to international lenders
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The result was an often agonisingly slow process of to and fro, with troika officials regularly departing in frustration about Greek foot-dragging
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is not only the troika's emphasis on austerity that has caused the Greek people so much pain
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As important was that huge adjustments were foisted upon an extraordinarily rigid economy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Despite much effort to open up mollycoddled sectors since 2010, Greece is still one of Europe's most overregulated economies
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Sluggish bureaucracies and exaggerated form-filling are the main reason Greece's exports have not rebounded like those of Spain, Portugal and Ireland
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The absence of a reliable land registry is holding back investment
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: An unreformed social security system still benefits better-off households more than the destitute
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the tax burden on ordinary people has risen
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: wealthy individuals and companies can still often evade their dues
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And wages in the public sector have fallen - but nowhere near as fast as those in the private sector, despite starting from a much higher level
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Greek politicians must get serious about removing the shackles from the economy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Economists think the benefits of structural reforms could materialise quickly in Greece's inefficient economy, and would be substantial
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development estimates that Greek businesses could save hundreds of millions of euros a year if the government scrapped burdensome regulations
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The Greek thinktank IOBE calculates that improvements to the business and investment environment could lift GDP by more than 2% in just two years
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: steps to increase competition in industries and services would have an even bigger impact
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Greece has started building a sounder economy on the wreckage of a public sector bubble and a strangulated private sector
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The costs have been exorbitant
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It would be a real Greek tragedy if the country's next government squandered the potential gains and reversed the process
paragraphs.label: assumption
